items.message:
River levels remain high at the Tewks. Upper Pound, Mythe, Haw Bridge and Sandhurst river gauges as a result of recent rainfall. Consequently, some flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue today, 28/12/2021. Currently no impact is forecast at the Gloucester gauge. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the River Severn from Tewkesbury to Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley, Maisemore, and Severn Ham, Tewkesbury may fill. Rain showers are forecast during the next 24 hours, river levels in these gauge locations are expected to remain elevated but either steady or fall slowly in these gauge locations. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Our incident response staff are checking defences. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 9am on 29/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road. River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast. This message will be updated this evening, 28/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Diglis (Worcester), Kempsey Yacht Club and Saxons Lode river gauges as a result of recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 28/12/2021. Flooding may affect low lying land and Roads adjacent the River from Highley to Tewkesbury. Other locations that may be affected include Stourport, Holt Fleet, Worcester, Kempsey, Severn Stoke, Upton upon Severn, South Quay, Diglis Parade and the Hylton Road towpath. Flooded drains may affect the racecourse and Worcester County cricket ground. New Street Gate is closed at Upton upon Severn due to flooding and may be impassable. Diglis has now peaked and is falling slowly, Kempsey Yacht Club has peaked and is falling slowly, Saxons Lode has also peaked and is falling slowly. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Our incident response staff are checking defences. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 9am on 29/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen and remain high at the Lugwardine river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall over the past few days. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue for the next couple of days. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop. Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days and we expect river levels to remain high. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 09:00 on 29/12/21, or if the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Sandyford Brook, Ridings Brook, Saredon Brook

items.message:
River levels are high but steady at the Milford river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland remains.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Sow between Great Bridgeford and Shugborough, the River Penk between Coven and Stafford, the Sandyford Brook, the Rising Brook, the Ridings Brook and the Saredon Brook.   Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
Further rainfall is possible over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated this evening, 28/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message:
River Levels remain high at the Sherborne Lake river gauge but are falling. Standing water on low lying land and roads may remain throughout Monday 27/12/21. The forecast is for generally dry weather, with some isolated showers on Monday 27/12/21 and Tuesday 28/12/21. Further, persistent rainfall is forecast on Wednesday 29/12/21, which may make river levels rise again. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.  
This message will be updated Tuesday morning, 28/12/21, or as the situation changes.

"River levels remain high at the Willington Cableway & Shardlow river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane. Current river level at Willington river gauge is 2.53m and at Shardow river gauge is 1.87m.   
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 29/12/21, or as the situation changes."

floodArea.county: Shropshire, Staffordshire, Telford and Wrekin, Wrexham

items.message: River levels have risen and remain high at the Tern - Walcot river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall over the past few days. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected today, 28/12/2021. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington. As further rainfall is expected river levels will remain high for the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow morning 29/12/2021 by 09:00, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Kempsey Yacht Club river gauge as a result of recent rainfall. Flooding may still affect low lying land and Squires walk in the area of the Hatfield Brook Kempsey. Kempsey Flood Alleviation scheme may be operational today, 28/12/2021. Kempsey Yacht Club has now peaked and is falling slowly. Rain showers are forecast during the next 24 hours, river levels are expected to remain elevated but generally continue to fall slowly in this gauge location. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Our incident response staff are checking defences. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated by 9am on 29/12/2021, or if the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
items.message: River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Lilbourne river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding is reducing. Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to River Avon between Stanford and Rugby, River Swift between Cosford and Rugby and Clay Coton Brook between Yelvertoft and Lilbourne. River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 28/12/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Eathorpe river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding is reducing.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Leam between Grandborough and Leamington including Kites Hardwick, Birdingbury, Marton, Eathorpe, Hunningham and Offchurch and the River Itchen between Southam and Marton including Long Itchington    
  River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated this evening, 28/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.message: Over the last several days we have seen heavy rainfall in the Middle Nene area. This means that the River Nene and associated tributaries have risen and remain high, which has led to flooding of low lying land and roads close to the river. River water levels are starting to come down but we expect them to remain high overnight. Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels, and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Please do not attempt to drive through flood water. This message will be updated in the morning on Tuesday, 28th December, or as the situation changes.

River levels have fallen at the Cappenham river gauge bur remain high downstream at Newport Pagnell Cemetery river gauge. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is still possible.  We expect flooding to affect River Tove from Towcester to Cosgrove, including Silverstone Brook   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high for a few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated this evening, 28/12/21, or as the situation changes.

Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.   We expect river levels to remain high for a few days.

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

River levels are high on the Middle River Roding as a result of persistent rainfall over the last few days. River levels are expected to remain high throughout today, Tuesday 28th December. 

Flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside gardens is possible, particularly around Loughton and Abridge. 

We are closely monitoring the situation, checking rivers for blockages and clearing debris from structures. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  

This message will be updated this evening, 28/12/21, or as the situation changes.

Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Blythe between Cheswick Green and Blyth End. River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. items.description: River Beult from Pluckley and Bethersden to Hampstead Lock at Yalding
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: This Flood Alert remains in force as river levels are rising again at Smarden in response to further heavy rainfall last night. Flooding could affect low lying land and roads again between Smarden and Staplehurst from 8am today, Tuesday 28 December. River levels are expected to peak in at Smarden this afternoon but river levels will remain high until Wednesday morning, 29 December. Property flooding is not expected. Further light rainfall is forecast today.  We are monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are checking the watercourses in the area. Please remain aware of your local situation. This message will be updated by 8pm on Tuesday 28 December, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Mardyke to the River Thames at Purfleet
items.message: River levels are now returning to normal. The forecast is for no significant rainfall for today. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: River Ray and its tributaries from Shipton Lee to and including Islip

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ray, Wootten Brook, Doddershall Brook, Tetchwick Brook, Lugershall Brook, Murswell Hill Brook, Cutters Brook, Piddington Brook, Blackthorn Brook, Panshill Brook, Studley Wood Brook, Beckley Brook, Oddington Brook, Gallos Brook, Chipping Farm Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high and continue to rise slowly on the lower River Ray following recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low-lying land, footpaths and roads is expected to continue today (28/12/21), especially in areas between Lower Arncott and Islip. 
Showers are forecast to clear this morning leaving a predominantly dry day. We expect river levels on the Lower River Ray to continue rising slowly through the day, before stabilising this evening (28/12/21). Levels will  remain high over the coming days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, many of which will be flooded. 
This message will be updated this evening, 28/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Evenlode from Moreton in Marsh to Cassington and also the River Glyme at Wootton and Woodstock
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high on the River Glyme but have fallen below the flood risk threshold on the River Evenlode. 
Showers are forecast to clear this morning leaving a predominantly dry day. River levels on the River Glyme are slowly rising in response to recent rainfall. River levels on the River Evenlode are expected to continue dropping slowly.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this evening, 28/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, although standing water and debris may remain on the floodplain. Showers are forecast to clear this morning (28/12/21) leaving a predominantly dry day.
We continue to monitor the situation. 
Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

River levels remain high at the Besford Bridge river gauge as a result of recent rainfall.  Consequently, it is possible flooding of roads and farmland will continue today, 28/12/2021.  Flooding may still affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the Brooks from Webheath to Defford.  Other locations that may be affected include Crowle, Wickenham, Peopleton, Pinvin and Pershore.  Local fords may also be flooded.  Rain showers are forecast during the next 24 hours, river levels are expected to remain elevated but generally continue to fall in this gauge location.  

We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Our incident response staff are checking defences and clearing weed screens. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 9am on 29/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the River Avon from Abbotts Salford to Tewkesbury. Other locations that may be affected include Offenham, Evesham, Twyning and the Eckington Road. Bredon has now peaked and is falling slowly. Rain showers are forecast during the next 24 hours, river levels are expected to remain elevated but generally continue to fall slowly in this gauge location. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Our incident response staff are checking defences and clearing weed screens. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Following a further band of rain moving across the East Devon area on Monday morning, river levels will continue to remain high on the Rivers Clyst, Culm and their tributaries.

Flooding of low lying land and roads close to the river is possible throughout today, Monday 27/12/2021. No flooding to properties is currently forecast. Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.

We are constantly monitoring river levels and will update this message on Tuesday, 28/12/2021, or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Otter and Sid, and Exmouth area
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Following a further band of rain moving across the east Devon area on Monday morning, river levels are once again beginning to rise on the Rivers Otter, Sid and in the Exmouth area.

Flooding of low lying land and roads close to the river is possible throughout today, Monday 27/12/2021. No flooding to properties is currently forecast. Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.

We are constantly monitoring river levels and will update this message on Tuesday, 28/12/2021, or earlier if the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: River levels have risen as a result of heavy rainfall yesterday. Minor flooding of low lying land along the River Medway is expected from 7am this morning, 28 December.  We expect flooding to affect the riverside footpaths in the Maidstone, East Farleigh and Teston area for most of the day today. River levels are expected to  peak in Maidstone later this afternoon but river levels will remain high until Wednesday morning, 29 December. Property flooding is not expected. Further light rainfall is forecast today.  We are monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are checking our sluices and structures between Yalding and Allington to ensure the river can flow freely. Please remain aware of your local situation.  This message will be updated  by 8pm on Tuesday 28 December, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Rother and its tributaries from Turks Bridge to the Royal Military Canal
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: River levels have risen as a result of heavy rainfall yesterday. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads around the Etchingham, Robertsbridge and Newenden areas. The River Rother is expected to peak this afternoon at Etchingham and this evening at Robertsbridge. River levels will remain high until Wednesday morning 29 December. Property flooding is not expected. Further light rainfall is forecast today. We are monitoring the situation and our incident response staff have been checking the watercourses and structures throughout the area. Please avoid using low lying footpaths or roads near the river during this time. This message will be updated by 8pm on Tuesday 28 December, or as the situation changes.

items.message: This Flood Alert remains in force as river levels remain high and have risen again in response to further rainfall last night. Minor flooding could continue to affect low lying land and roads along the Rivers East Stour and the Great Stour upstream of Ashford town centre. Property flooding is not expected. We are monitoring the situation and our incident response staff have been out checking the watercourses and structures throughout the area. The flood storage reservoir on the East Stour near Aldington is retaining some flood water to assist river drainage through Mersham and Ashford. This message will be updated by 8pm on Tuesday 28 December, or as the situation changes.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

Our incident response staff are clearing debris from weed screens.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high on the River Thame downstream of Aylesbury following recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low-lying land, footpaths and roads is expected to continue overnight, especially in areas closest to the river between Thame and Dorchester. 
Showers are forecast to clear this morning (28/12/21) leaving a predominantly dry day. River levels are dropping upstream of Thame, now stable in the Thame area, and continuing to rise slowly between Stadhampton and Dorchester. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff will be in the area clearing weed/trash screens. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and avoid contact with flood water. 
This message will be updated this evening, 28/12/21, or as the situation changes.

The Western Rother is still high at Lodsbridge, near Selham and Fittleworth, following Monday evenings rain. Another 5mm of rain is forecast for this morning (Tuesday 28/12/2021), but river levels should not rise by much at all. Minor flood impacts will continue to affect fields, rural roads and gardens between Lodsbridge, near Selham and Fittleworth, but river levels should slowly fall along this stretch during Tuesday afternoon. The Western Rother is already much lower between Liss and Midhurst. Another 5mm of rain is currently forecast for Wednesday morning (29/12/2021). This is not expected to be enough to cause a large rise in water levels, but will delay the rivers return to normal in Fittleworth until the weekend. Please remain prepared for potential flood impacts while the Western Rother is higher than normal, and there is still rain in the forecast. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 on 28/12/2021.

Property flooding is not currently expected.

We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

items.message: Over the last several days we have seen heavy rainfall in the East and West Glens area. This means that the East and West Glens have risen and remain high, which has led to flooding of low lying land and roads close to the rivers. River water levels are starting to come down but we expect them to remain high overnight. Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels, and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Please do not attempt to drive through flood water. This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels are falling, but some standing water on low lying land and roads may remain. Monday 27/12/21 will be a largely dry day, with some showery rain. Further, more persistent rain is forecast on Wednesday 29/12/21, we will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  
Our incident response staff are clearing debris from weed screens.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.

The Powdermill Stream and Combe Haven are higher than normal, but are now slowly falling, following Monday evenings rain. Minor flooding will continue to affect fields, rural roads, the Recreation Ground and a small number of gardens in Crowhurst. Water will also affect Bexhill Road Recreation Ground in Bulverhythe. 5mm of rain is currently forecast for both this morning (Tuesday 28/12/2021) and Wednesday morning (29/12/2021), which shouldnt generate a significant rise in river levels. Instead, in Crowhurst the Powdermill Stream should slowly fall nearer to normal by Thursday (30/12/2021). In Bulverhythe, the Combe Haven is unlikely to return to normal before the weekend. As a precaution you may like to keep flood protection products installed, or close to hand, in Crowhurst, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 on 28/12/2021.

The Cuckmere and Bull Rivers are higher than normal following Monday evening's rain. 5mm of rain is forecast for this morning (Tuesday 28/12/2021). River levels are not expected to rise much, but could rise a small amount and will remain high throughout Tuesday. Minor flooding will continue to affect fields, rural roads and gardens, including on Mill Lane, Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly. In Alfriston, the Cuckmere is predicted to slowly rise throughout Tuesday and minor flood impacts could affect North Street, Willows Car Park, River Lane, The Old Clergy House and Deans Place Hotel, Alfriston. Another 5mm of rain is forecast for Wednesday morning. This is not expected to be enough to cause a large rise in levels, but will delay the rivers return to normal until at least Thursday in Hellingly, and probably the weekend in Alfriston. Please plan to avoid driving through routes susceptible to flooding, including Mill Lane, Hellingly and North Street, Alfriston. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 on 28/12/2021.

This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. 
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. 
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 5 hours. 
We continue to monitor the situation. 
Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high and continue to rise on the Lower Cherwell following recent rainfall.  Therefore, flooding of low-lying land, footpaths and roads is expected to continue, especially in areas between Upper Heyford and Kidlington. 
Showers are forecast to clear this morning (28/12/21) leaving a predominantly dry day. River levels in the Upper Heyford area are now stable, levels between Kidlington and Oxford continue to rise slowly. We expect river levels to remain high over the coming days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, many of which will be flooded. 
This message will be updated this evening, 28/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: River levels remain high on the River Brede after heavy rainfall over the last few days. Localised flooding of low lying land and roads is possible between Rye and Winchelsea between 4:30pm and 8:30pm on Tuesday 28 December, as high river levels are expected to coincide with the next high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected. We are monitoring the situation and our incident response staff have been checking the watercourses and structures throughout the area. Please avoid using low lying footpaths or roads near the river during this time. This message will be updated by 9pm on Tuesday 28 December, or as the situation changes.

Overnight we have seen heavy rainfall in the River Ise and Alledge Brook area. This means that the River Ise and Alledge Brook have risen and remain high, which has led to flooding of low lying land and roads close to the river. River water levels are starting to come down but we expect them to remain high overnight. Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels, and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Please do not attempt to drive through flood water. This message will be updated in the morning on Tuesday, 28th December, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Rhee in Central Bedfordshire, Hertfordshire and Cambridgeshire
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

Water levels in the Eastern Yar remain high and stable. In the last 3 days, almost 40mm of rain has been recorded at Wroxall. At Alverstone, the river will peak around midday today (Tuesday 28/12/2021). At Sandown, levels are stable but not expected to peak until tomorrow morning (Wednesday 29/12/2021), with continued minor impact flooding to Golf Links Road and Moreton Common Road. Ditches near Fort Holiday Park will struggle to drain. Although unsettled conditions continue this week, lower rainfall totals are forecast and the situation will improve. We are operating the sluice at Bembridge to reduce levels at Brading Marshes. Neap tides continue over the next 2 days, so the river will have limited opportunity to drain to sea and water will pond on Brading Marshes. This will not affect property. We continue to monitor the forecast and keep the river free of any reported blockages. This Flood Alert will be updated or removed by 16:00 on 29/12/2021.

The River Uck is now falling following Monday evenings heavy rain. Minor flood impacts will continue to affect fields, rural roads and gardens today (Tuesday 28/12/2021) all along the River Uck, but particularly in Isfield. 5mm of rain is currently forecast for both this morning (28/12/2021) and Wednesday morning (29/12/2021), which could cause a small increase in water levels, but they should not be as high as Monday night. It is more likely that Tuesday and Wednesdays rain will delay the River Ucks return to normal until Thursday. You may like to keep flood protection products installed in Isfield and Buxted as a precaution while uncertainty and rain remains in the forecast, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 on 28/12/2021.

The River Adur is higher than normal and slowly rising following Mondays rain. Another 5mm of rain is currently forecast for both this morning (Tuesday 28/12/2021) and Wednesday morning (29/12/2021). Minor flooding will continue to affect fields and gardens, and could affect the A281 at Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury. The River Adur could continue to slowly rise until approximately 20:00 on Tuesday 28/12/2021, but probably by no more than 30cm. Wednesdays rain will likely delay the river's return to normal until Friday. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including the A281 at Mock Bridge. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 on 28/12/2021.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message:
River levels are rising at the Sutton Gault river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall. We expect flooding to affect The Causeway at Sutton Gault   
This information is correct as of 07:30 on Tuesday 28th December. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 7 centimetres of water currently on the road. There are currently no issues on the Earith or Welney Causeways. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.  We expect river levels to continue rising into tomorrow.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with Cambridgeshire Highways, who will decide whether to close the road.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated this afternoon, 28/12/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising at the Sutton Gault river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall.  
This information is correct as of 07:30 on Tuesday 28th December. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 7 centimetres of water currently on the road. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places.
This alert applies to SUTTON GAULT CAUSEWAY ONLY.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.  We expect river levels to continue rising into tomorrow.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with Cambridgeshire Highways, who will decide whether to close the road.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated this afternoon, 28/12/21, or as the situation changes.

The River Ouse is high near Barcombe following Monday evenings heavy rain. Minor flooding affecting fields, rural roads, including Barcombe Mills Road, gardens, and the Anchor Inn near Barcombe Mills will continue. The Ouse should begin to fall in Barcombe by 10:00 on 28/12/2021, but is unlikely to return to normal until Wednesday morning. Another 5mm of rain is currently forecast for both this morning (Tuesday 28/12/2021) and Wednesday morning (29/12/2021). While we do not currently expect river levels to rise by much, this additional rain could further slow the rivers fall. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Barcombe Mills Road. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 21:00 on 28/12/2021.

The River Uck at Buxted has fallen from its overnight peak. Another 5mm of rain is currently forecast for both this morning (Tuesday 28/12/2021) and Wednesday morning (29/12/2021). However, we do not currently expect river levels to rise by much. Minor flooding affecting fields, rural roads and gardens could still be possible through Buxted, near the White Hart pub and areas around Hempstead Mill on Hempstead Lane, Uckfield. A Flood Alert will remain in force to account for uncertainty in the weather forecast. Riverside properties may like to keep flood protection products in place until Wednesday (29/12/2021), if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this message if our confidence increases of property flooding.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: East Sussex, Kent, Surrey, West Sussex

items.message: River levels have risen as a result of heavy rainfall yesterday. Minor flooding of low lying land along the River Medway is expected from 6am this morning, Tuesday 28 December.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads which is expected around the Hartfield and Penshurst areas until later this afternoon.   River levels are expected to  peak at around 9am this morning in Penshurst but river levels will remain high until later this afternoon or early evening, Tuesday 28 December. Property flooding is not expected. Further light rainfall is forecast today.  We are monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. Please remain aware of your local situation.  This message will be updated  by 8pm on Tuesday 28 December, or as the situation changes.

As a result of large waves and strong winds, tides will be at their highest around 12:00 noon today, the 28/12/2021. Great care should be taken along the Dorset coast. Heavy spray, strong winds and some large waves will make walking close to exposed coastlines especially dangerous today. Rainfall over the Christmas period has made cliffs highly unstable, and you are advised to stay well clear of both the edge and the foot of cliffs. 
We are closely monitoring the conditions and will update this message as the situation develops.
